Name.BusinessNameLine1: Pioneer Center FOR HUMAN SERVICES CO Jeff Kurth

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: to empower individuals to achieve their full potential.
IRS990.MissionDescription: to work with children and adults to explore opportunities for personal accomplishment through education, vocational and community participation.
IRS990.Description: GROUP HOME CARE FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES: RESIDENTIAL SERVICES INCLUDE EIGHT GROUP HOMES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, FIVE GROUP HOMES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH MENTAL ILLNESSES OR SUBSTANCE ABUSE ISSUES, A SUPPORTED APARTMENT PROGRAM, A RENTAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM, AND TRANSITIONAL AND EMERGENCY SHELTERS FOR THE HOMELESS.

Activity2.Description: SERVICES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES: VOCATIONAL SERVICE PROGRAMS PROVIDE A RANGE OF EVALUTATIVE MEASUREMENTS TO CAREFULLY ASSESS THE NEEDS OF PERSONS WITH MENTAL ILLNESS AND/OR DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES IN ORDER TO ASSIST PARTICIPANTS IN SECURING AND RETAINING EMPLOYMENT IN THE COMMUNITY AND ALSO OFFERS TRAINING REHABILITATIVE COUNSELING AND HANDS ON JOB SKILLS.

Activity3.Description: SERVICES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES: COMMUNITY SERVICE PROGRAMS OFFER SUPPORT AND SERVICES TO PERSONS WITH MENTAL ILLNESS AND/OR DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES BY DEVELOPING STRATEGIES AND ASSISTING THEM IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN THEIR COMMUNITY LIVING THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF DAILY LIVING SKILLS.

ActivityOther.Description: SERVICES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES: DAY SERVICES INCLUDE PROGRAMS TO ASSIST INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE SEVERE AND MULTIPLE DISABILITIES IN DEVELOPING BASIC LIFE SKILLS. PIONEER CENTER'S SOAR PROGRAM OFFERS VOCATIONAL TRAINING, RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, SOCIALIZATION OPPORTUNITIES AND COMMUNITY INTEGRATION TO ADULTS 55 AND OVER. THE TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY PROGRAM PROVIDES CASE MANAGEMENT, FAMILY SUPPORT, AND VOCATIONAL SERVICES THAT ENABLE CLIENTS TO OBTAIN AND MAINTAIN EMPLOYMENT IN THE COMMUNITY. PADS ALSO OPERATES A DAY SERVICES CENTER AND PROVIDES SUPPORTIVE SERVICES INCLUDING CHILDCARE AND TRANSPORTATION. VOICE PROGRAM PROVIDES DIRECT SERVICES TO SEXUAL ASSAULT VICTIMS.

SERVICES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES, GENERAL: THE EARLY INTERVENTION PROGRAM ASSISTS IN THE DEVELOPMENT SKILLS OF INFANTS, TODDLERS AND YOUNG CHILDREN, 0-5 YEARS OF AGE, THROUGH SPEECH, OCCUPATIONAL, PHYSICAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL THERAPIES.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Rep Payee accounts are established when the Social Security Administration (SSA) makes a determination that the beneficiary (client) is unable (i.e., does not have the ability) to handle his or her own SSA benefits and will therefore need a representative to handle these benefits. Usually a family member is solicited for this task; however, if an appropriate family member or natural support is not available, a Pioneer Center staff person may be appointed as the rep payee. Pioneer Center uses bank reconciliations to track the transactions for rep payee clients, but does not own the funds. The Client Council accounts were established as a method of record-keeping for transactions from client pop and snack purchases, client craft fairs, and other client fundraising activities. Clients use seed money from the Client Council funds to conduct these fundraisers. Proceeds from these activities are then spent by the Client Council for parties and fun activities for the clients. Client Council funds are not Pioneer Center property. Pioneer Center acts only as an agent for the administration of those funds--providing a tracking mechanism for collecting, disbursing, and accounting for the funds. Pioneer Center has a contingent liability with respect to a post-retirement agreement with its President/CEO. These funds are owned by the President/CEO, but are recorded on the Pioneer Center balance sheet.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Effective July 1, 2009, the Agency adopted the guidance in the FASB Codification topic related to uncertainty in income taxes which prescribes a comprehensive model for recognizing, measuring, presenting and disclosing in the financial statements uncertain tax positions that the Agency has taken or expects to take in its tax returns. Under the guidance, the Agency may recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is "more likely than not" that it is sustainable, based on its technical merits. The tax benefits recognized in the financial statements from such a position should be measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement with a taxing authority having full knowledge of all relevant information. The adoption of the guidance had no effect on the Agency's financial statements as of July 1, 2009 and resulted in no adjustment for unrecognized income tax benefits for the year ended June 30, 2010. The Agency believes that it has appropriate support for the positions taken on its returns.

IRS990ScheduleG.ExplanationIfNo: Not required by the state of Illinois.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: All assistance is given only to those who are active clients and meet the eligibility requirements of a particular program at Pioneer. This eligibility is based on financial need, diagnosed disability, homelessness or other diagnosis / criteria. The eligibility is monitored by various funding agencies and the internal quality assurance process at Pioneer.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: An investment broker is used to sell publicly traded securities donated to the organization.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The audit/finance committee reviews and approves the Form 990 and a copy is provided to the Board of Directors for their review before filing with the Internal Revenue Service.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors and key employees review the conflict of interest policy annually and any disclosures are dealt with accordingly.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Human Resources Committee, a subcommittee of the Board, reviews the President's salary annually. The salaries for all Vice Presidents are also reviewed annually by the Audit Committee. Both Committees use industry guides to review salary levels for the appropriate positions. Recommendations are made to the Board who approve the compensation which is appropriately docemented in the meeting minutes.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are available upon request.
The process has not changed from the prior year.
